elements.content: Four novel transition metal oxyfluorides, [Zn­(pz)3]­[MoO2F4]·0.1H2O (1), [Zn­(pz)2F2]­[Zn­(pz)3]2[WO2F4]2 (2), [Cd­(pz)4]­[Cd­(pz)4(H2O)]­[MoO2F4]2·0.625H2O (3), and [Zn­(mpz)3]2[MoO2F4]2 (4) (pz = pyrazole; mpz = 3-methyl pyrazole) have been synthesized. Compounds 1 and 4 contain helical chains. Compound 2 accommodates zigzag chains, and compound 3 has quasi-one-dimensional linear chains. The variable chain structures are found to be attributable to the different structure-directing anionic groups and hydrogen bonding interactions. Compound 4 crystallized in the noncentrosymmetric (NCS) polar space group, Pna21, is nonphase-matchable (Type I), and reveals a moderate second-harmonic-generation (SHG) efficiency (10 × α-SiO2). The observed SHG efficiency of compound 4 is due to the small net polarization occurring from the arrangement of ZnN3F2 trigonal bipyramids. Spectroscopic and thermal characterizations along with calculations for the title materials are reported.

elements.content:
The net moment occurring from ZnN3F2 trigonal bipyramids are responsible for the SHG of noncentrosymmetric zinc molybdenum oxyfluoride chains.

Introduction

Rational design and construction of compounds crystallizing in noncentrosymmetric (NCS) space groups have been of great interest attributed to their intriguing physical properties. The interesting characteristics expected from crystalline compounds with NCS structures may be utilized in various functional application fields, i.e., lasers, detectors, memories, energy systems, and photolithography. Among many approaches toward the functional materials containing NCS structures, combining the basic building units (BBUs) exhibiting specific moments have drawn huge attentions. Specifically, the combination of distortive octahedra containing early transition metals (ETM), polarizable polyhedra with late transition metals (LTMs), and organic ligands through solvothermal reactions have been extensively explored. In fact, the individual net dipole moments arising from the asymmetric BBUs were key factors for the polarity engineering. In addition, the combination of unsymmetrical BBUs resulted in interesting structures such as isolated molecules, chains, layers, and frameworks. The structural diversity found from mixed metal oxyfluoride compounds has been intimately related to the hard–soft acid–base chemistry: The hard ETM acids with high oxidation states tend to be coordinated by the hard bases such as F– and O2–, whereas the soft LTM with low oxidation states tend to be connected by the soft organic bases. Several mixed metal oxyfluoride materials have successfully suggested important clues for the asymmetric environment including the structure-directing properties. Here, we discovered four new mixed transition metal oxyfluorides revealing various chain structures by combining distorted ETM octahedra (Mo6+ and W6+), polarizable LTM cations (Zn2+ and Cd2+), and heterocyclic ligands [pyrazole (pz) and 3-methylpyrazole (mpz)]. Synthesis, structural description, spectroscopic characterization, and thermal properties for the title compounds are provided. Detailed second-harmonic-generation (SHG) properties and the origin of the SHG for the helical chains with NCS structure are also presented.

elements.content:
Caution: Hydrofluoric acid is toxic and corrosive!

Synthesis

ZnO (99.0%, Waco), CdO (99.5%, Aldrich), MoO3 (99.5%, Alfa Aesar), WO3 (99.5%, Daejung), C3H4N2 (pyrazole) (98%, Alfa Aesar), C4H6N2 (3-methypyrazole) (97%, Alfa Aesar), and HF (aq. 48 wt %, J.T Baker) were used as received. Crystals of all the reported compounds were grown via hydrothermal reactions. For [Zn­(pz)3]­[MoO2F4]·0.1H2O (1), 4.00 × 10–3 mol (0.326 g) of ZnO, 4.00 × 10–3 mol (0.576 g) of MoO3, 2.40 × 10–2 mol (1.630 g) of pyrazole, 2.00 × 10–2 mol (0.834 g) of aqueous HF (48%), and 0.324 mL of water were combined. For [Zn­(pz)2F2]­[Zn­(pz)3]2[WO2F4]2 (2), 5.00 × 10–3 mol (0.407 g) of ZnO, 5.00 × 10–3 mol (1.159 g) of WO3, 1.00 × 10–2 mol (0.681 g) of pyrazole, 2.50 × 10–2 mol (1.042 g) of aqueous HF (48%), and 0.811 mL of water were combined. For [Cd­(pz)4]­[Cd­(pz)4(H2O)]­[MoO2F4]2·0.625H2O (3), 5.00 × 10–3 mol (0.642 g) of CdO, 5.00 × 10–3 mol (0.720 g) of MoO3, 3.00 × 10–2 mol (2.042 g) of pyrazole, 2.50 × 10–2 mol (1.042 g) of aqueous HF (48%), and 1.621 mL of water were combined. For [Zn­(mpz)3]2[MoO2F4]2 (4), 1.00 × 10–3 mol (0.081 g) of ZnO, 1.00 × 10–3 mol (0.144 g) of MoO3, 6.00 × 10–3 mol (0.498 g) of 3-methylpyrazole, 5.00 × 10–3 mol (0.208 g) of aqueous HF (48%), and 0.180 mL of water were combined. Each reaction mixture was loaded in autoclaves with 23 mL Teflon cups. After tightly sealing, the autoclaves were heated to 150 °C for 72 h (24 h for compound 1) and slowly cooled to room temperature at a rate of 6 °C h–1. Colorless crystals of compounds 1–4 were obtained by vacuum filtration in 84, 28, 62, and 59% yields, respectively, based on ZnO or CdO. Compound 4 crystallizing in a NCS space group was deposited to NCS Materials Bank (http://ncsmb.knrrc.or.kr).

elements.content: Single crystal X-ray diffraction data for compounds 1–4 were collected on a Bruker SMART BREEZE diffractometer (Mo Kα radiation) with a 1K CCD area detector at room temperature and on a BL2D-SMC at the Pohang Light Source II using 0.65000 Å radiation at 100 K. A colorless block (0.332 mm × 0.440 mm × 0.516 mm) for compound 1, a colorless block (0.335 mm × 0.403 mm × 0.562 mm) for compound 2, a colorless block (0.028 mm × 0.028 mm × 0.063 mm) for compound 3, and a colorless block (0.232 mm × 0.425 mm × 0.440 mm) for compound 4 were selected. The structure solutions and refinements were obtained by SHELXS-97 and SHELXL-97, respectively, in the software package WinGX-98. Crystallographic data for the title compounds are tabulated in .

Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data of the reported crystalline materials were obtained on a Bruker D8-Advance diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation with 40 kV and 40 mA in the 2θ range of 5–70° with a step size of 0.02° for 0.1 s. The measured PXRD patterns for the pure polycrystalline samples were in good agreement with the calculated data generated from single crystal X-ray diffraction experiments (see the Supporting Information).

Infrared (IR) spectra for the title compounds were collected by a Thermo Scientific Nicolet 6700 FT-IR spectrometer in the range of 400–4000 cm–1 at room temperature.

UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectra for the synthesized materials were obtained on a Varian Cary 500 scan UV–vis–NIR spectrophotometer in the spectral range of 200–2000 nm at room temperature. The measured reflectance data were converted to absorbance using the Kubelka–Munk function.

elements.content: SHG measurements were performed by using a modified Kurtz-NLO measurement system with a DAWA Q-switched Nd:YAG solid state laser (1064 nm radiation operating at 20 Hz). Polycrystalline sample of NCS compound 4 was ground and sieved into various particle size ranges (<20, 20–45, 45–63, 63–90, 90–125, 125–150, 150–200, and 200–250 μm) and packed into separate capillary tubes. Polycrystalline α-SiO2 with the particle size range of 45–63 μm was also used as a standard sample to make a suitable comparison. The detailed description of the SHG measurement setup was published earlier.

elements.content: Compound 1 with the highly symmetric tetragonal space group, I41/a, shows a helical chain structure consisting of pyrazole, MoO2F4, and ZnN3F2 polyhedra (a). A unique Mo6+ is in a distorted octahedral moiety and is coordinated by two oxide and four fluoride ligands. Specifically, the MoO2F6 octahedron distorts toward a distinct local C2 direction and exhibits two short Mo–O [1.678(3) Å and 1.687(3) Å], two intermediate Mo–F [1.913(3) Å and 1.947(3) Å], and two long Mo–F [2.099(2) Å and 2.117(2) Å] bonds. Another unique cation, Zn2+ is in a trigonal bipyramidal geometry with three nitrogen and two fluoride ligands. While three nitrogen atoms are coordinated in the equatorial locations, two fluorine ligands are linked to Zn2+ in the axial positions of the ZnN3F2 trigonal bipyramid. The Zn–N bond distances range 1.994(4)–2.030(4) Å and the Zn–F bond lengths are 2.070(2)–2.111(2) Å. The C–C, C–N, and N–N bond lengths in pyrazole ligands are 1.323(8)–1.380(7) Å, 1.311(6)–1.362(6) Å, and 1.335(5)–1.348(5) Å, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Result and Discussion

Structures

[Zn(pz)3][MoO2F4]⋅0.1H2O (1)

Compound 1 with the highly symmetric tetragonal space group, I41/a, shows a helical chain structure consisting of pyrazole, MoO2F4, and ZnN3F2 polyhedra (a). A unique Mo6+ is in a distorted octahedral moiety and is coordinated by two oxide and four fluoride ligands. Specifically, the MoO2F6 octahedron distorts toward a distinct local C2 direction and exhibits two short Mo-O [1.678(3) Å and 1.687(3) Å], two intermediate Mo-F [1.913(3) Å and 1.947(3) Å], and two long Mo-F [2.099(2) Å and 2.117(2) Å] bonds. Another unique cation, Zn2+ is in a trigonal bipyramidal geometry with three nitrogen and two fluoride ligands. While three nitrogen atoms are coordinated in the equatorial locations, two fluorine ligands are linked to Zn2+ in the axial positions of the ZnN3F2 trigonal bipyramid. The Zn-N bond distances range 1.994(4)-2.030(4) Å and the Zn-F bond lengths are 2.070(2)-2.111(2) Å. The C-C, C-N, and N-N bond lengths in pyrazole ligands are 1.323(8)-1.380(7) Å, 1.311(6)-1.362(6) Å, and 1.335(5)-1.348(5) Å, respectively.

elements.content: Ball-and-stick models of compound 1 in the ac-plane revealing (a) an asymmetric unit and (b) helical chains (blue, Mo; cyan, Zn; red, O; green, F; gray, C; purple, N.). (c) Helical chain structures of compound 1 in the ac- and ab-plane revealing intrachain hydrogen bonds between pyrazole C–H and fluoride (blue dotted lines), between pyrazole N–H and oxide or fluoride (red dotted lines), and between water O–H and fluoride (green dotted lines). Hydrogen atoms were omitted for clarity.

Hydrogen atoms were omitted for clarity.

elements.content: The corner-sharing of Mo(1)­O2F4 and Zn(1)­(pz)3F2 units via F(2) and F(4) forms helical chains that are running through the c-direction (b). Two longer Mo–F bonds in [MoO2F4]2– octahedra, which are located in the trans position of two shorter Mo–O bonds, are more nucleophilic. Thus, corners with longer Mo–F bonds in [MoO2F4]2– octahedra are shared by Zn2+ cations through fluoride ligands (see b). In other words, the vertex-sharing between cis-directing [MoO2F4]2– groups and ZnN3F2 trigonal bipyramids through F– ligands results in the infinite helical chain structures. Intrachain hydrogen bonds between pyrazole C–H and fluoride ligands [3.177(6)–3.184(6) Å; blue dotted lines in c] and between pyrazole N–H and oxide or fluoride ligands [2.854(5)–3.177(5) Å; red dotted lines in c] are found in the helical chains. Water molecules residing in the inter helical chain space also reveal significant hydrogen bonding interactions with fluoride ligands [2.75(5) Å; green dotted lines in c]. Compound 1 can be represented as a helical chain of {[Mo(1)­O2/1F2/1F2/2]− [Zn(1)­(pz)3F2/2]+}0. Bond valence sum calculations for Zn2+ and Mo6+ result in values of 2.117 and 6.011, respectively.
elements.clean_text: The corner-sharing of Mo(1)O2F4 and Zn(1)(pz)3F2 units via F(2) and F(4) forms helical chains that are running through the c-direction (b). Two longer Mo-F bonds in [MoO2F4]2- octahedra, which are located in the trans position of two shorter Mo-O bonds, are more nucleophilic. Thus, corners with longer Mo-F bonds in [MoO2F4]2- octahedra are shared by Zn2+ cations through fluoride ligands (see b). In other words, the vertex-sharing between cis-directing [MoO2F4]2- groups and ZnN3F2 trigonal bipyramids through F- ligands results in the infinite helical chain structures. Intrachain hydrogen bonds between pyrazole C-H and fluoride ligands [3.177(6)-3.184(6) Å; blue dotted lines in c] and between pyrazole N-H and oxide or fluoride ligands [2.854(5)-3.177(5) Å; red dotted lines in c] are found in the helical chains. Water molecules residing in the inter helical chain space also reveal significant hydrogen bonding interactions with fluoride ligands [2.75(5) Å; green dotted lines in c]. Compound 1 can be represented as a helical chain of {[Mo(1)O2/1F2/1F2/2]- [Zn(1)(pz)3F2/2]+}0. Bond valence sum calculations for Zn2+ and Mo6+ result in values of 2.117 and 6.011, respectively.

elements.content: Compound 2 reveals a unidimensional structure that is composed of pyrazole, WO2F4, ZnN3OF, ZnN3F2, and ZnN2OF2 polyhedra (a). Two unique W6+ cations are in highly distorted WO2F4 octahedra. The distortions in both WO2F4 octahedra occur toward a C2 direction, which leads two short W–O [1.701(6)–1.761(4) Å and 1.693(7)–1.729(5) Å], two intermediate W–F [1.863(4) × 2 Å and 1.873(5) × 2 Å], and two long W–F [2.002(5)–2.046(4) Å and 1.988(4)–2.063(4) Å] bond distances. Three independent Zn2+ are all in trigonal bipyramidal environment with nitrogen, oxygen, and fluoride atoms. However, each unique Zn2+ cation is coordinated by different combination of the ligands and three distinct trigonal bipyramids, i.e., ZnN3OF, ZnN3F2, and ZnN2OF2 are monitored. The observed Zn–N, Zn–O, and Zn–F bond lengths range 2.003(5)–2.049(4) Å, 2.035(5)–2.122(5) Å, and 1.955(3)–2.144(3) Å, respectively. Pyrazole ligands coordinated to the equatorial position of ZnN3OF, ZnN3F2, and ZnN2OF2 trigonal bipyramids exhibit N–N, C–N, and C–C bond distances of 1.335(6)–1.353(6) Å, 1.319(8)–1.334(8) Å, and 1.324(9)–1.400(12) Å, respectively.

Compound 2 reveals a unidimensional structure that is composed of pyrazole, WO2F4, ZnN3OF, ZnN3F2, and ZnN2OF2 polyhedra (a). Two unique W6+ cations are in highly distorted WO2F4 octahedra. The distortions in both WO2F4 octahedra occur toward a C2 direction, which leads two short W-O [1.701(6)-1.761(4) Å and 1.693(7)-1.729(5) Å], two intermediate W-F [1.863(4) × 2 Å and 1.873(5) × 2 Å], and two long W-F [2.002(5)-2.046(4) Å and 1.988(4)-2.063(4) Å] bond distances. Three independent Zn2+ are all in trigonal bipyramidal environment with nitrogen, oxygen, and fluoride atoms. However, each unique Zn2+ cation is coordinated by different combination of the ligands and three distinct trigonal bipyramids, i.e., ZnN3OF, ZnN3F2, and ZnN2OF2 are monitored. The observed Zn-N, Zn-O, and Zn-F bond lengths range 2.003(5)-2.049(4) Å, 2.035(5)-2.122(5) Å, and 1.955(3)-2.144(3) Å, respectively. Pyrazole ligands coordinated to the equatorial position of ZnN3OF, ZnN3F2, and ZnN2OF2 trigonal bipyramids exhibit N-N, C-N, and C-C bond distances of 1.335(6)-1.353(6) Å, 1.319(8)-1.334(8) Å, and 1.324(9)-1.400(12) Å, respectively.

elements.content: As seen in a, the building blocks, W(1)­O2F4, W(2)­O2F4, Zn(1)­(pz)3OF, Zn(2)­(pz)3F2, and Zn(3)­(pz)2OF2 share their corners through O(1), F(1), F(4), and F(8) along the [100] direction and form [WO2F4]­[Zn­(pz)3]­[WO2F4]­[Zn­(pz)3]­[Zn­(pz)2OF2] linear pentamers. Each [WO2F4]­[Zn­(pz)3]­[WO2F4]­[Zn­(pz)3]­[Zn­(pz)2OF2] pentamer shares O(4) along the approximate c-direction and generates an infinite zigzag chain that is parallel to the a-direction (b). The [WO2F4]2– anionic octahedra in compound 2 contain four highly nucleophilic ligands, which allows either cis or trans coordination. Thus, while one of the [WO2F4]2– anionic group is coordinated to the Zn center in a trans-directing fashion, another [WO2F4]2– is connected in a cis-directing fashion. The different linkages ultimately produce a zigzag chain structure of compound 2 (b). Interestingly, intrachain hydrogen bonds between pyrazole N–H and fluoride ligands that range from 2.661(5) to 3.140(7) Å exist and influence the distortions of WO2F4 and ZnN2OF2 polyhedra as well as the orientation of nitrogen atoms in pz ligands (c). Compound 2 can be considered as a neutral chain of {[W(1)­O1/1 O 1/2F3/1 F 1/2]0.5– [W(2)­O1/1 O 1/2F3/1 F 1/2]0.5– [Zn(1)­(pz)3 O 1/2 F 1/2]0.5+ [Zn(2)­(pz)3F2/2]+ [Zn(3)­(pz)2 O 1/2F1/1 F 1/2]0.5–}0. Bond valence sum calculations indicate that Zn2+ and W6+ reveal values of 1.935–1.978 and 5.923–6.328, respectively.

elements.content: Compound 3 exhibits a quasi-one-dimensional structure that consists of distorted MoO2F4 and CdN4OF octahedra (a). Mo(1)­O2F4 and Mo(2)­O2F4 octahedra revealing local C3 octahedral distortions lead three short [1.693(2)–1.829(2) Å] and three long [1.980(2)–2.1080(19) Å] Mo–O­(F) lengths, whereas Mo(3)­O2F4 and Mo(4)­O2F4 octahedra exhibiting local C2 octahedral distortions give rise to two short [1.689(2)–1.757(2) Å], two intermediate [1.893(2)–1.951(2) Å], and two long [2.0160(19)–2.089(2) Å] Mo–O­(F) bond lengths. Based on the observed bond distances, some O and F atoms in Mo(1)­O2F4 and Mo(2)­O2F4 octahedra were found to be disordered. Specifically, whereas O(2)/F(2) and O(3)/F(3) in Mo(1)­O2F4 are statistically disordered with 0.62/0.38 and 0.38/0.62 ratio, respectively, O(6)/F(6) and O(7)/F(7) in Mo(2)­O2F4 are disordered with 0.44/0.56 and 0.56/0.44 ratio, respectively. Four independent Cd2+ are in octahedral moiety with oxide, fluoride, and nitrogen atoms as well. It should be noticed that all nitrogen atoms are located in the equatorial position of CdN4OF octahedra attributed to the coordination of pyrazole ligands. Also, Cd(1)2+ and Cd(3)2+ are coordinated by water molecules (a). The Cd–N, Cd–O, and Cd–F bond distances range 2.291(3)–2.342(3) Å, 2.300(2)–2.389(2) Å, and 2.278(2)–2.316(2) Å, respectively. The C–C, C–N, and N–N bond lengths in pyrazole ligands are 1.345(6)–1.435(6) Å, 1.321(5)–1.389(6) Å, and 1.329(5)–1.358(4) Å, respectively.

elements.content: Cd­(1)­N4OF, Mo(1)­O2F4, Cd(2)­N4OF, and Mo(2)­O2F4 share the vertices via F or O atoms and form tetramers. All the equatorial positions of octahedra of Cd(1)2+ and Cd(2)2+ cations are coordinated by pyrazole ligands (b). Similar tetramers that are laid perpendicular to the previously described tetramers are also formed by corner-sharing of Cd(3)­N4OF, Mo(3)­O2F4, Cd(4)­N4OF, and Mo(4)­O2F4 octahedra through F or O atoms. Water molecules reside in the intertetramer space (b). For compound 3, more negative charges associated on O and its trans F ligands in [MoO2F4]2– octahedra are covalently bridged with trans-directing cadmium centered octahedra, which results in the quasi-1D linear chain structure (see b). Intratetramer hydrogen bonds between pyrazole N–H and oxide or fluoride ligands [2.733(4)–3.402(5) Å; red dotted lines in b] as well as intra- and intertetramer hydrogen bonds between pyrazole C–H and oxide or fluoride ligands [3.040(17)–3.464(17) Å; blue dotted lines in b] exist in compound 3. The backbone of compound 3 may be expressed as neutral tetramers of {[Cd(1)­(py)4(H2O)F 1/2]1.5+ [Mo(1)­O1/1 O 1/2F3/1 F 1/2]0.5– [Cd(2)­(py)4 O 1/2 F 1/2]0.5+ [Mo(2)­O2/1F3/1 F 1/2]1.5–}0 {[Cd(3)­(py)4(H2O)F 1/2]1.5+ [Mo(3)­O1/1 O 1/2F3/1 F 1/2]0.5– [Cd(4)­(py)4 O 1/2 F 1/2]0.5+ [Mo(4)­O2/1F3/1 F 1/2]1.5–}0. Bond valence calculations for Cd2+ and Mo6+ are 2.101–2.154 and 5.685–5.839, respectively.

elements.content: Compound 4 exhibiting a helical unidimensional structure consists of 3-methyl pyrazole, MoO2F4, and ZnN3F2 polyhedra (a). Similar to WO2F4 octahedra in compound 2, two unique Mo6+ show local C2 octahedral distortions with two oxide and four fluoride ligands and reveal two short Mo–O [1.668(3)–1.703(3) Å and 1.681(3)–1.691(3) Å], two intermediate Mo–F [1.917(2)–1.921(3) Å and 1.901(3)–1.928(3) Å], and two long Mo–F [2.097(3)–2.127(2) Å and 2.100(3)–2.142(3) Å] bond lengths. Also, two unique Zn2+ cations are in trigonal bipyramidal geometry with nitrogen and fluorine atoms with the observed Zn–N and Zn–F bond distances of 2.010(4)–2.021(4) Å and 2.016(2)–2.175(2) Å, respectively. 3-methyl pyrazole ligands bonded to the Zn(1)­N3F2 and Zn(1)­N3F2 trigonal bipyramids reveal C–C, C–N, and N–N lengths of 1.353(7)–1.513(7) Å, 1.322(6)–1.343(6) Å, and 1.345(5)–1.354(5) Å, respectively.

elements.content: IR spectra confirmed that the title compounds contain all the corresponding metal–ligand bonds such as Mo–O, Mo–F, W–O, W–F, Zn–F, Zn–N, and Cd–N bonds. The peaks occurring at ca. 900–957 and 531–556 cm–1 might be attributed to the vibrations from Mo–O and Mo–F bonds, respectively. The peaks observed at 951 and 910 cm–1 should be symmetric and antisymmetric W–O stretching vibrations, respectively, and the peak found at ca. 531 cm–1 is attributable to W–F vibration. The peaks occurring at ca. 771–804 and 756 cm–1 are assigned to the vibrations of Zn–N and Cd–N bonds, respectively. In addition, bands in the region 1400–1420, 3100–3500, 1520–1540, and 1400–1600 cm–1 could be assigned for N–H bending, N–H stretching, C–H bending, and CC stretching, respectively, in the pyrazole and 3-methyl pyrazole ligands.

IR Spectroscopy

IR spectra confirmed that the title compounds contain all the corresponding metal-ligand bonds such as Mo-O, Mo-F, W-O, W-F, Zn-F, Zn-N, and Cd-N bonds. The peaks occurring at ca. 900-957 and 531-556 cm-1 might be attributed to the vibrations from Mo-O and Mo-F bonds, respectively. The peaks observed at 951 and 910 cm-1 should be symmetric and antisymmetric W-O stretching vibrations, respectively, and the peak found at ca. 531 cm-1 is attributable to W-F vibration. The peaks occurring at ca. 771-804 and 756 cm-1 are assigned to the vibrations of Zn-N and Cd-N bonds, respectively. In addition, bands in the region 1400-1420, 3100-3500, 1520-1540, and 1400-1600 cm-1 could be assigned for N-H bending, N-H stretching, C-H bending, and CC stretching, respectively, in the pyrazole and 3-methyl pyrazole ligands.

elements.content: UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectra for the title compounds were collected and their band gaps were obtained using the Kubelka–Munk function (). The determined band gaps for compounds 1–4 are approximately 3.08, 3.73, 3.11, and 4.00 eV, respectively. The bandgaps for the compounds primarily originate from the interorbital electronic transitions between the conduction and the valence bands. Each band edge consists of d10 orbitals on M2+, d0 orbitals on M6+, and M2+–ligand at a bit higher levels. The observed band gaps match well with the previously published values of compounds containing the filled d10 and empty d0 electronic configurations of the transition metals. The optical absorption shifts into the higher energy region by the substitution of Mo6+ for W6+. The larger bandgap of compound 4 compared to that of compound 1 should be attributable to the coordination of more electron-rich 3-methylpyrazole ligands to Zn2+.

UV-Vis Spectroscopy

UV-vis diffuse reflectance spectra for the title compounds were collected and their band gaps were obtained using the Kubelka-Munk function (). The determined band gaps for compounds 1-4 are approximately 3.08, 3.73, 3.11, and 4.00 eV, respectively. The bandgaps for the compounds primarily originate from the interorbital electronic transitions between the conduction and the valence bands. Each band edge consists of d10 orbitals on M2+, d0 orbitals on M6+, and M2+-ligand at a bit higher levels. The observed band gaps match well with the previously published values of compounds containing the filled d10 and empty d0 electronic configurations of the transition metals. The optical absorption shifts into the higher energy region by the substitution of Mo6+ for W6+. The larger bandgap of compound 4 compared to that of compound 1 should be attributable to the coordination of more electron-rich 3-methylpyrazole ligands to Zn2+.

elements.content: The thermal behaviors for the reported compounds are quite similar. All the title compounds do not show any weight loss up to ca. 150 °C. Compounds 1 and 3 reveal gradual weight losses of 0.37% and 0.76% between 150 and 200 °C attributable to the loss of the occluded water (calcd 0.39% and 0.80%, respectively). Upon further heating, compounds 1–4 lose weights dramatically at 550, 550, 500, and 600 °C, respectively, by losing the decomposed organic and fluoride ligands [calculated (experimental): 1, 51.34% (49.90%); 2, 42.76% (43.24%); 3, 50.96% (51.67%); 4, 47.74% (52.93%)]. The completely decomposed polycrystalline samples after heating compounds 1–4 above 700 °C were identified as ZnMoO4, ZnWO4, CdMoO4, and ZnMoO4, respectively, which was supported by PXRD measurements.

TGA

The thermal behaviors for the reported compounds are quite similar. All the title compounds do not show any weight loss up to ca. 150 °C. Compounds 1 and 3 reveal gradual weight losses of 0.37% and 0.76% between 150 and 200 °C attributable to the loss of the occluded water (calcd 0.39% and 0.80%, respectively). Upon further heating, compounds 1-4 lose weights dramatically at 550, 550, 500, and 600 °C, respectively, by losing the decomposed organic and fluoride ligands [calculated (experimental): 1, 51.34% (49.90%); 2, 42.76% (43.24%); 3, 50.96% (51.67%); 4, 47.74% (52.93%)]. The completely decomposed polycrystalline samples after heating compounds 1-4 above 700 °C were identified as ZnMoO4, ZnWO4, CdMoO4, and ZnMoO4, respectively, which was supported by PXRD measurements.

elements.content: Polar NCS compound 4 has an SHG efficiency of about 10 × α-SiO2 and is nonphase-matchable (). To explain the observed SHG efficiency, unsymmetrical units of compound 4 have been closely analyzed. Each mpz organic ligand with asymmetric environment in a unit cell reveals polarization toward specific directions. However, the net moment arising from the mpz ligand completely cancels (see a). The same phenomenon occurs for Mo6+ cations in the MoO2F4 octahedra. Although Mo6+ cations are displaced from the center toward the edges of two cis-oxides and result in C2 octahedral distortions, the net moment arising from the MoO2F4 distorted octahedra in a unit cell cancels (see b). The Zn2+ cations in Zn(1)­N3F2 trigonal bipyramids have moments toward the [011] and [01̅1] directions (c), whereas the Zn2+ cations in Zn(2)­N3F2 trigonal bipyramids reveal moments toward the [101] and [1̅01] directions (d). Thus, the small net moment occurs from Zn(1)­N3F2 and Zn(2)­N3F2 trigonal bipyramids in the [001] direction, which should be the origin of moderate SHG efficiency for compound 4.

elements.content: The local dipole moments of ZnN3F2 and MoO2F4 in compound 4 are calculated to be 1.59–1.78 and 4.09–4.30 D (Debyes), respectively, which are similar to those published values. Also, the net moment for a unit cell is calculated to be ca. 1.44 D along the [001] direction, which agrees well with the above-mentioned net polarization analysis. Local dipole moments and the extent of out-of-center distortion (Δd) for other polyhedra in all the title compounds were also calculated. The calculated dipole moments for ZnN3F2, ZnN3OF, ZnN2OF2, CdN4OF, MoO2F4, and WO2F4 polyhedra in compounds 1–3 are about 0.83–1.78, 0.20, 0.71, 1.79–2.83, 2.72–4.30, and 0.82–1.33 D, respectively. The Δd values for MoO2F4 and WO2F4 octahedra in the title compounds can be also determined to be 0.61–0.92 and 0.60–0.64, respectively. The calculated local dipole moments and Δd values for all the constituent polyhedra are tabulated in .

Both of compounds 1 and 4 containing the similar building units, i.e., MoO2F4 and ZnN3F2 polyhedra reveal helical chain structures. However, compound 1 is centrosymmetric (CS), whereas compound 4 is NCS. The presence of methyl groups in the coordinated organic ligands seems to be very important for determining the centricity of the reported compounds. The bulkier mpz ligands containing the methyl group in compound 4 create a steric hindrance, which results in the alignment of the [MoO2F4]2–octahedra in the helical oxyfluoride and the macroscopic polar structure. In addition, the mpz ligand in compound 4 is more electron-rich, which is attributed to the electron-donating methyl groups compared to that of pz ligand. Once the electron-rich mpz ligand is coordinated to Zn2+ cation, a net polarization and the subsequent polar structure can be easily generated by the alignment of ZnN3F2 polyhedra in compound 4. However, compound 1 coordinated by the pz ligand that does not contain a net moment tends to crystallize in a CS space group.
elements.clean_text:
Centrosymmetric versus Noncentrosymmetric Structures

Both of compounds 1 and 4 containing the similar building units, i.e., MoO2F4 and ZnN3F2 polyhedra reveal helical chain structures. However, compound 1 is centrosymmetric (CS), whereas compound 4 is NCS. The presence of methyl groups in the coordinated organic ligands seems to be very important for determining the centricity of the reported compounds. The bulkier mpz ligands containing the methyl group in compound 4 create a steric hindrance, which results in the alignment of the [MoO2F4]2-octahedra in the helical oxyfluoride and the macroscopic polar structure. In addition, the mpz ligand in compound 4 is more electron-rich, which is attributed to the electron-donating methyl groups compared to that of pz ligand. Once the electron-rich mpz ligand is coordinated to Zn2+ cation, a net polarization and the subsequent polar structure can be easily generated by the alignment of ZnN3F2 polyhedra in compound 4. However, compound 1 coordinated by the pz ligand that does not contain a net moment tends to crystallize in a CS space group.

elements.content: Four novel transition metal oxyfluorides, [Zn­(pz)3]­[MoO2F4]·0.1H2O (1), [Zn­(pz)2F2]­[Zn­(pz)3]2[WO2F4]2 (2), [Cd­(pz)4]­[Cd­(pz)4(H2O)]­[MoO2F4]2 0.625H2O (3), and [Zn­(mpz)3]2[MoO2F4]2 (4) were synthesized. Each distinctive structure-directing polyhedron and hydrogen bonding mode result in diverse chain structures. Compound 1 and 4 consist of helical chains. Compound 2 contains zigzag chains, and compound 3 is composed of quasi-linear chains. Compound 4 exhibiting a polar NCS structure shows SHG intensity of 10 × α-SiO2 and is nonphase-matchable. Detailed structural analysis along with dipole moment calculations propose that the observed SHG properties are owing to the polarization occurring from ZnN3F2 polyhedra in the [001] direction.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Four novel transition metal oxyfluorides, [Zn(pz)3][MoO2F4]⋅0.1H2O (1), [Zn(pz)2F2][Zn(pz)3]2[WO2F4]2 (2), [Cd(pz)4][Cd(pz)4(H2O)][MoO2F4]2 0.625H2O (3), and [Zn(mpz)3]2[MoO2F4]2 (4) were synthesized. Each distinctive structure-directing polyhedron and hydrogen bonding mode result in diverse chain structures. Compound 1 and 4 consist of helical chains. Compound 2 contains zigzag chains, and compound 3 is composed of quasi-linear chains. Compound 4 exhibiting a polar NCS structure shows SHG intensity of 10 × α-SiO2 and is nonphase-matchable. Detailed structural analysis along with dipole moment calculations propose that the observed SHG properties are owing to the polarization occurring from ZnN3F2 polyhedra in the [001] direction.

cln_elements.content:
Caution: Hydrofluoric acid is toxic and corrosive!

Synthesis

ZnO (99.0%, Waco), CdO (99.5%, Aldrich), MoO3 (99.5%, Alfa Aesar), WO3 (99.5%, Daejung), C3H4N2 (pyrazole) (98%, Alfa Aesar), C4H6N2 (3-methypyrazole) (97%, Alfa Aesar), and HF (aq. 48 wt %, J.T Baker) were used as received. Crystals of all the reported compounds were grown via hydrothermal reactions. For [Zn­(pz)3]­[MoO2F4]·0.1H2O (1), 4.00 × 10–3 mol (0.326 g) of ZnO, 4.00 × 10–3 mol (0.576 g) of MoO3, 2.40 × 10–2 mol (1.630 g) of pyrazole, 2.00 × 10–2 mol (0.834 g) of aqueous HF (48%), and 0.324 mL of water were combined. For [Zn­(pz)2F2]­[Zn­(pz)3]2[WO2F4]2 (2), 5.00 × 10–3 mol (0.407 g) of ZnO, 5.00 × 10–3 mol (1.159 g) of WO3, 1.00 × 10–2 mol (0.681 g) of pyrazole, 2.50 × 10–2 mol (1.042 g) of aqueous HF (48%), and 0.811 mL of water were combined. For [Cd­(pz)4]­[Cd­(pz)4(H2O)]­[MoO2F4]2·0.625H2O (3), 5.00 × 10–3 mol (0.642 g) of CdO, 5.00 × 10–3 mol (0.720 g) of MoO3, 3.00 × 10–2 mol (2.042 g) of pyrazole, 2.50 × 10–2 mol (1.042 g) of aqueous HF (48%), and 1.621 mL of water were combined. For [Zn­(mpz)3]2[MoO2F4]2 (4), 1.00 × 10–3 mol (0.081 g) of ZnO, 1.00 × 10–3 mol (0.144 g) of MoO3, 6.00 × 10–3 mol (0.498 g) of 3-methylpyrazole, 5.00 × 10–3 mol (0.208 g) of aqueous HF (48%), and 0.180 mL of water were combined. Each reaction mixture was loaded in autoclaves with 23 mL Teflon cups. After tightly sealing, the autoclaves were heated to 150 °C for 72 h (24 h for compound 1) and slowly cooled to room temperature at a rate of 6 °C h–1. Colorless crystals of compounds 1–4 were obtained by vacuum filtration in 84, 28, 62, and 59% yields, respectively, based on ZnO or CdO. Compound 4 crystallizing in a NCS space group was deposited to NCS Materials Bank (http://ncsmb.knrrc.or.kr).

cln_elements.content: The thermal behaviors for the reported compounds are quite similar. All the title compounds do not show any weight loss up to ca. 150 °C. Compounds 1 and 3 reveal gradual weight losses of 0.37% and 0.76% between 150 and 200 °C attributable to the loss of the occluded water (calcd 0.39% and 0.80%, respectively). Upon further heating, compounds 1–4 lose weights dramatically at 550, 550, 500, and 600 °C, respectively, by losing the decomposed organic and fluoride ligands [calculated (experimental): 1, 51.34% (49.90%); 2, 42.76% (43.24%); 3, 50.96% (51.67%); 4, 47.74% (52.93%)]. The completely decomposed polycrystalline samples after heating compounds 1–4 above 700 °C were identified as ZnMoO4, ZnWO4, CdMoO4, and ZnMoO4, respectively, which was supported by PXRD measurements.
cln_elements.clean_text:
TGA

The thermal behaviors for the reported compounds are quite similar. All the title compounds do not show any weight loss up to ca. 150 °C. Compounds 1 and 3 reveal gradual weight losses of 0.37% and 0.76% between 150 and 200 °C attributable to the loss of the occluded water (calcd 0.39% and 0.80%, respectively). Upon further heating, compounds 1-4 lose weights dramatically at 550, 550, 500, and 600 °C, respectively, by losing the decomposed organic and fluoride ligands [calculated (experimental): 1, 51.34% (49.90%); 2, 42.76% (43.24%); 3, 50.96% (51.67%); 4, 47.74% (52.93%)]. The completely decomposed polycrystalline samples after heating compounds 1-4 above 700 °C were identified as ZnMoO4, ZnWO4, CdMoO4, and ZnMoO4, respectively, which was supported by PXRD measurements.
